Title of the project: Deployment of 4G Improved Cooking Stoves in Yen Bai Province, Viet Nam

The main objective of this project is the installation of energy-efficient Improved Cooking Stoves (ICS) in households that traditionally rely on wood for cooking. The project is implemented across various villages within the districts of Van Chan, Tram Tau, and Van Yen in Yen Bai Province, Viet Nam. These regions are characterized by a significant reliance on traditional biomass for cooking, making them ideal candidates for the introduction of energy-efficient cooking technologies. The ICS will result in reduced firewood consumption, leading to climate change mitigation in a sustainable manner. The overall objectives are the reduction of greenhouse gases, conservation of forests and woodlands, and improved health conditions of ICS users due to enhanced indoor air quality.

The ICS promoted under this project activity is a single pot '4G' improved cookstove made of steel and produced in the host country. The design results in higher pressure in the stove than the atmosphere, hence raising the airflow rate in the improved cookstove tunnel, as it is heated at the bottom. This way, the top point of the improved cookstove experiences more pressure and heat. The lifespan of the ICS is 5 years. The thermal efficiency of the 4G ICS is 30.00%.

The scenario existing prior to the implementation of the project is the actual baseline scenario, which is equal to the existing common practice by the ICS users. In the absence of the project activity, the equivalent amount of thermal energy would be generated using firewood in three-stone open fires to meet the cooking energy demand. This method is highly inefficient and results in high levels of firewood consumption and emissions. The absence of the project would mean continued reliance on this unsustainable practice, exacerbating deforestation and indoor air pollution issues.

The primary mechanism for reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions is the installation of energy-efficient ICS in households that traditionally use wood for cooking. By lowering firewood consumption, the project mitigates climate change impacts. Furthermore, the reduction in firewood demand helps decrease deforestation rates, thus conserving forests and woodlands. Improved indoor air quality resulting from the use of ICS also contributes to better health outcomes for users. The project aids in the reduction of non-renewable biomass usage, promoting natural forest recovery and potential reforestation.

The estimates of annual average and total GHG emission reductions for the chosen crediting period are 43,093 tCO2e/annum and 430,930 tCO2e respectively. These figures underscore the significant environmental benefits expected from the project's implementation.

This summary provides a comprehensive understanding of the project's nature, implementation strategy, and anticipated environmental impact, highlighting its contribution to sustainable development and climate change mitigation.
